mentions.context: GATB, HipMer, MEGAHIT and OPERA-MS assembled unique genomes with 100% recall and precision.
HipMer introduced the fewest mismatches (67 mismatches per 100 kb) on the marine data.
HipMer also had the fewest misassemblies on the common and unique marine genomes, while GATB had the fewest misassemblies on common strain-madness genomes and SPAdes on unique ones.
HipMer had the fewest mismatches (67) per 100 kb on the marine and GATB on the strain-madness data (98, Fig. 1b).
SPAdes, which was not assessed in the first challenge, was among the top submissions for most metrics.
HipMer had the highest strain recall and precision for common and unique marine genomes (4.5 and 20.4% recall, 100% precision each).
MEGAHIT, A-STAR, HipMer and Ray Meta 29 required 10×, 13.2×, 13.9× and 19.5× coverage, respectively.
MEGAHIT used the least memory (42 GB), followed by GATB (56.6 GB).
MetaBAT v.2.13.33 was the fastest (1.07 and 0.05 h) and most memory efficient binner (maximum memory usage 2.66 and 1.5 GB) on both datasets.
DIAMOND on contigs ranked best for completeness (67.6%) and Ganon on short reads for accuracy (77.1%) on the plant-associated data.
HipMer 20 ranked best across metrics and datasets, and on marine data, as it produced few mismatches with a comparably high genome fraction and NGA50 (Table 1).
MetaHipMer was the fastest assembler and required 2.1 h to process marine short reads, 3.3× less than the second fastest assembler, MEGAHIT.
The SPAdes 26 hybrid submission had a higher NGA50 of 43,014, but was not the best ranking SPAdes submission.
For HipMer, single-sample assembly might be preferable if coverage is sufficient and closely related strains are expected.

All scripts and parameters for these steps are provided in the Supplementary Material and on GitHub (https://github.com/CAMI-challenge/ second_challenge_evaluation/tree/master/scripts/data_generation).
Only HipMer recovered a unique genome split across 16 samples from pooled samples, while a unique, single-sample genome was reconstructed well by all assemblers with both strategies.
Both MetaBAT and CONCOCT were substantially (roughly 11× and 4×) faster than their CAMI 1 versions.
Only DIAMOND correctly classified viral contigs, although with low purity (50%), completeness and accuracy (both 3%).
GATB, HipMer, MEGAHIT and OPERA-MS assembled unique genomes with 100% recall and precision.
MEGAHIT, A-STAR, HipMer and Ray Meta 29 required 10×, 13.2×, 13.9× and 19.5× coverage, respectively.
However, MetaHipMer used the most memory (1,961 gigabytes (GB)).
Software and scripts used for data analyses and Figs.
GATB, HipMer, MEGAHIT and OPERA-MS assembled unique genomes with 100% recall and precision.
MEGAHIT, A-STAR, HipMer and Ray Meta 29 required 10×, 13.2×, 13.9× and 19.5× coverage, respectively.
On unique genomes, HipMer ranked first for the marine and strain-madness datasets.
It was followed by DIAMOND, which ran roughly 500× and 910× as long on the marine and strain-madness GSAs, respectively.
It was followed by MetaPhlAn v.2.9.22 (average 0.22, 0.32 genus, 0.39 species).
biocontainers/quast, AMBER 36 and https://quay.io/repository/biocontainers/ cami-amber, OPAL 42 : https://quay.io/repository/biocontainers/cami-opal).
The hybrid assemblers GATB (mean completeness 60.1%) and OPERA-MS (mean 47.1%) recovered the most complete 16S sequences.

The hybrid assemblers GATB and OPERA-MS produced the longest contigs aligning to 16S rRNA genes, with a median length of 8,513 and 4,430 base pairs (bp), respectively, while for other assemblers median contig length was less than the average 16S rRNA gene length (1,503 bp).
This was 30% less than Ray Meta, the best performing method also participating in CAMI 1. OPERA-MS improved on MEGAHIT in NGA50 by 1,645 (6%), although using twice as much (long-and short-read) data.
On strain-madness data, GATB 21,22 ranked best, with HipMer in second place.
For short-read assembly, MEGAHIT had the highest contiguity on the marine (NGA50 26,599) and strain-madness data (NGA50 4,793).
For common marine genomes, HipMer ranked best across metrics and GATB for common strain-madness genomes.

Overall, mOTUs v.2.5.1 and MetaPhlAn v.2.9.22 ranked best across taxonomic ranks and metrics on the marine and plant-associated datasets, and mOTUs v.cami1 and MetaPhlAn v.2.9.22 on the strain-madness dataset (Table 1, Supplementary Tables 33, 35 and 37 and Supplementary Fig. 12).
MEGAHIT, A-STAR, HipMer and Ray Meta 29 required 10×, 13.2×, 13.9× and 19.5× coverage, respectively.

Immediately afterward, gold standard and MEGAHIT 19 assemblies were provided for both datasets.
Assemblies were very accurate for ABySS and HipMer (<1% divergence).

Benchmarked software outputs are available on Zenodo (https://zenodo.org/communities/cami/). Raw sequencing data for the newly sequenced and previously unpublished genomes are available with BioProject numbers PRJEB50270, PRJEB50297, PRJEB50298, PRJEB50299, PRJEB43117 and PRJEB37696.

Sourmash_gather v.3.3.2_k31 on PacBio reads and MetaPhlAn v.3.0.7 had the highest purity for genus (98.5%, 95.5%) and species ranks (64.4%, 68.8%) and sourmash_gather v.3.3.2_k21_sr the highest completeness (genus 61.9%, species 53.8%).
MEGAHIT used the least memory (42 GB), followed by GATB (56.6 GB).

On strain-madness data, GATB 21,22 ranked best, with HipMer in second place.

The ten-sample 100 GB marine dataset was created with CAMISIM from BIOM profiles of a deep-sea environment, using 155 newly sequenced marine isolate genomes from this environment and 622 genomes with matching taxonomic provenance from MarRef 66 , a manually curated database with completely sequenced marine genomes.

Compared to software assessed in the first CAMI challenge, A-STAR had a 20% higher genome fraction on strain-madness data, almost threefold that of MEGAHIT.
ABySS 24 created the fewest misassemblies for the marine and GATB for the strain-madness data (Fig. 1c).
Mean completeness for short-read assemblies ranged from 29.6% (HipMer) to 36.9% (MEGAHIT).
For common marine genomes, HipMer ranked best across metrics and GATB for common strain-madness genomes.
HipMer had the fewest mismatches (67) per 100 kb on the marine and GATB on the strain-madness data (98, Fig. 1b).
Several assemblers reconstructed high-copy circular elements well, with HipMer, MEGAHIT, SPAdes and A-STAR reconstructing all (Fig. 1g).
Several assemblers reconstructed high-copy circular elements well, with HipMer, MEGAHIT, SPAdes and A-STAR reconstructing all (Fig. 1g).
Mean completeness for short-read assemblies ranged from 29.6% (HipMer) to 36.9% (MEGAHIT).
A-STAR excelled in genome fraction, ranking first across all four data partitions and HipMer had the fewest mismatches.
For each sample, 2 Gb of paired-end short and long-read sequences were generated with CAMISIM, respectively, using the same parameters and error profiles as in CAMI 1 (ref.

For all assemblers and 16S sequences, there were 17 cross-genome chimeras, reported by MetaQUAST as interspecies translocations: ten for MEGAHIT, five for A-STAR and one each for HipMer and SPAdes, while GATB, ABySS and OPERA-MS did not produce chimeric sequences.
HipMer also had the fewest misassemblies on the common and unique marine genomes, while GATB had the fewest misassemblies on common strain-madness genomes and SPAdes on unique ones.
Several assemblers reconstructed high-copy circular elements well, with HipMer, MEGAHIT, SPAdes and A-STAR reconstructing all (Fig. 1g).
We assessed the contributions of assembly quality by comparing with the binning results on MEGAHIT assemblies.

For genomes unique to a single sample, but common in pooled samples (LjRoot109, LjRoot170), HipMer performed better on single samples, while OPERA-MS was better on pooled samples (Supplementary Fig. 5), and other assemblers traded a higher genome fraction against more mismatches.

All scripts and parameters for these steps are provided in the Supplementary Material and on GitHub (https://github.com/CAMI-challenge/ second_challenge_evaluation/tree/master/scripts/data_generation).
Several assemblers reconstructed high-copy circular elements well, with HipMer, MEGAHIT, SPAdes and A-STAR reconstructing all (Fig. 1g).

For reproducibility, participants could submit a Docker container containing the complete workflow, a bioconda script or a software repository with detailed installation instructions specifying all parameter settings and reference databases used.
This was 30% less than Ray Meta, the best performing method also participating in CAMI 1. OPERA-MS improved on MEGAHIT in NGA50 by 1,645 (6%), although using twice as much (long-and short-read) data.
Short-read assemblers achieved genome fractions of up to 10.4% on strain-madness and 41.1% on marine data, both by MEGAHIT 19 .
For several assemblers, preprocessing using read quality trimming or error correction software, such as trimmomatic 27 or DUK 28 , improved assembly quality (Supplementary Tables 2 and3).
Vamb always had the best purity, while UltraBinner had the best ARI for the marine GSA, MetaWRAP for the strain-madness GSA and MetaBAT 39,40 for MAs and plant-associated assemblies.

We evaluated 95 results for 18 binner versions on short-read assemblies: 22 for the strain-madness GSAs, 17 for the strain-madness MEGAHIT assembly (MA), 19 for marine MA, 15 for marine GSA, 12 for plant-associated GSA and ten for the plant-associated MA (Supplementary Tables 9101112131415).
MetaHipMer was the fastest assembler and required 2.1 h to process marine short reads, 3.3× less than the second fastest assembler, MEGAHIT.

Supplementary Table 2 specifies the evaluated programs, parameters used and installations options, including software repositories, Bioconda package recipes, Docker images, Bioboxes and BioContainers.

Supplementary Table 2 specifies the evaluated programs, parameters used and installations options, including software repositories, Bioconda package recipes, Docker images, Bioboxes and BioContainers.

While gold standards for short and hybrid assemblies included genome assemblies with more than 90% genome fraction and 3.3× coverage, SPAdes best assembled low coverage marine genomes, starting at 9.2×.

For all assemblers and 16S sequences, there were 17 cross-genome chimeras, reported by MetaQUAST as interspecies translocations: ten for MEGAHIT, five for A-STAR and one each for HipMer and SPAdes, while GATB, ABySS and OPERA-MS did not produce chimeric sequences.
We also updated Docker BioContainers implementing a range of commonly used performance metrics to include all metrics used in this evaluation (MetaQUAST 17 : https://quay.io/repository/
Three submissions correctly identified the causal pathogen, Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever orthonairovirus (CCHFV), using the taxonomic profilers MetaPhlAn v.2.2, Bracken v.2.5 and CCMetagen v.1.1.3
In addition, genome coverage, parameter settings and data preprocessing impacted assembly quality, while performances were similar across software MetaHipMer 2.0.1.2
In addition, genome coverage, parameter settings and data preprocessing impacted assembly quality, while performances were similar across software MetaHipMer 2.0.1.2
Compared to software assessed in the first CAMI challenge, A-STAR had a 20% higher genome fraction on strain-madness data, almost threefold that of MEGAHIT.
mOTUs v.2.5.1 (ref. 43 ) had completeness and purity above 80% at genus and species ranks on marine data, and Centrifuge v.1.0.4 beta (ref. 44 ) and MetaPhlAn v.2.9.22 (refs.
The highest NGA50 on common marine genomes was achieved by OPERA-MS, on common strain-madness genomes by A-STAR and on unique genomes in both datasets by SPAdes.

On the strain-madness data, mOTUs v.cami1 performed best in L1 norm across ranks (0.05 average), and also at genus and species with 0.1 and 0.15, followed by MetaPhlAn v.2.9.22 (0.09 average, 0.12 genus, 0.23 species).
HipMer also had the fewest misassemblies on the common and unique marine genomes, while GATB had the fewest misassemblies on common strain-madness genomes and SPAdes on unique ones.
While for GSA contigs the ground truth genome assignment is known, for the MA, we considered this to be the best matching genomes for a contig identified using MetaQUAST v.5.0.2.

Overall, mOTUs v.2.5.1 and MetaPhlAn v.2.9.22 ranked best across taxonomic ranks and metrics on the marine and plant-associated datasets, and mOTUs v.cami1 and MetaPhlAn v.2.9.22 on the strain-madness dataset (Table 1, Supplementary Tables 33, 35 and 37 and Supplementary Fig. 12).

Newly assembled and database genomes were taxonomically classified with CAMITAX 63 and used as input for microbial community and metagenome data simulation with CAMISIM 16 , based on the from_profile mode for the marine and plant-associated dataset and the de novo mode for the strain-madness datasets.

For all assemblers and 16S sequences, there were 17 cross-genome chimeras, reported by MetaQUAST as interspecies translocations: ten for MEGAHIT, five for A-STAR and one each for HipMer and SPAdes, while GATB, ABySS and OPERA-MS did not produce chimeric sequences.
Three submissions correctly identified the causal pathogen, Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever orthonairovirus (CCHFV), using the taxonomic profilers MetaPhlAn v.2.2, Bracken v.2.5 and CCMetagen v.1.1.3

For all assemblers and 16S sequences, there were 17 cross-genome chimeras, reported by MetaQUAST as interspecies translocations: ten for MEGAHIT, five for A-STAR and one each for HipMer and SPAdes, while GATB, ABySS and OPERA-MS did not produce chimeric sequences.

We assessed the average bin purity and genome completeness (and their summary using the F1-score), the number of high-quality genomes recovered, as well as the adjusted Rand index (ARI), using AMBER v.2.0.3 (ref. 36 ) (Methods).

For all assemblers and 16S sequences, there were 17 cross-genome chimeras, reported by MetaQUAST as interspecies translocations: ten for MEGAHIT, five for A-STAR and one each for HipMer and SPAdes, while GATB, ABySS and OPERA-MS did not produce chimeric sequences.

Several methods accurately reconstructed the alpha diversity of samples using the Shannon equitability; best (0.03 or less absolute difference to gold standards) across ranks on marine data were: mOTUs v.2.5.1, DUDes v.0.08 and v.cami1 and MetaPhlAn v.2.9.22 and v.cami1; on strain-madness data: DUDes v.cami1, mOTUs v.cami1 and MetaPhlAn v.2.9.22.

Illumina paired-end read data of 796 newly sequenced genomes, of which 224 stem from an Arabidopsis thaliana root environment, 176 from a marine environment 60 , 384 clinical Streptococcus pneumoniae strains and 12 strains from a murine gut environment, were assembled using a pipeline with the SPAdes 61 metagenome assembler (v.3.12).

Several methods accurately reconstructed the alpha diversity of samples using the Shannon equitability; best (0.03 or less absolute difference to gold standards) across ranks on marine data were: mOTUs v.2.5.1, DUDes v.0.08 and v.cami1 and MetaPhlAn v.2.9.22 and v.cami1; on strain-madness data: DUDes v.cami1, mOTUs v.cami1 and MetaPhlAn v.2.9.22.
